events.summary: Lili Boulanger, the musical sensation, burst into the world in the vibrant 9th arrondissement of Paris. With a family deeply rooted in music, it was clear from day one she was destined to be a superstar—and likely played her first orchestral piece while still in the crib!

By the age of two, Lili was already serenading her family with melodies she plucked from thin air—talk about a party trick! Thanks to her parents, both musicians, she was not only encouraged but practically enrolled in a 'how to be a genius' class.

In a dramatic twist worthy of a Broadway show, Lili collapsed during her first attempt at the prestigious Prix de Rome competition. Spoiler alert: she came back stronger the next year—no fainting allowed!

Lili made history by winning the Prix de Rome with her breathtaking cantata 'Faust et Hélène.' Not only was she the first woman to snag this honor, but she did it while also proving that makeup and melodrama can indeed go hand in hand!

The triumphant cantata 'Faust et Hélène' was brought to life, showcasing Lili's innovative flair—because who doesn't want to see Goethe's characters musically moping around? It was a hit and turned many heads, dramatically!
After her big win, Lili enjoyed the charm of Italy while working on several compositions. Her love for travel was almost as strong as her love for Italian pasta—an important detail!

events.event: Participation in World War I Support
events.summary: As the world was thrown into chaos, Lili and her sister Nadia stepped up to support French soldiers during the war. They basically became the dynamic duo of defense, showing that music and bravery can coexist beautifully!

In her final creative flourish, Lili composed several haunting pieces, including the 'Pie Jesu'—essentially her way of saying, 'I've got a lot left to say, but I need a little more time!' Such dedication to her art!

Lili Boulanger departed from this world at the tender age of 24, leaving behind a legacy of innovation that still makes composers leap with joy. She might have left us too soon, but trust us, her compositions are just getting started!

As a child, Lili was already composing, proving that she was not just a 'Boulanger' by name but also a master 'Boulanger' of notes, whipping up music that would make even seasoned composers raise an eyebrow.

events.event: First Woman to Win the Prix de Rome
events.summary: Lili entered the prestigious Prix de Rome competition, and in a twist that even she must have found hard to believe, she became the first female winner, showing everyone that women could indeed break glass ceilings in classical music!
She composed several major works, including 'D'un matin de printemps' and 'Psaume 130', solidifying her reputation as a composer who could stir hearts and rattle windows – talk about a multitasker!
